User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; zh-TW; rv:1.9.2.10) Gecko/20100922 Ubuntu/10.10 (maverick) Firefox/3.6.10
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; zh-TW; rv:1.9.2.10) Gecko/20100922 Ubuntu/10.10 (maverick) Firefox/3.6.10

The page has a buttom for login, it is outside of where it should be, I hope it can be inside of the area.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1.Open http://webmail.hinet.net/
2.Look the right side of the page.
3.You find the problem is.
Actual Results:  
Button out of the area.

Expected Results:  
Button inside the range.

Sorry I am a Taiwanese, I sometimes forget the correct spelling of words.
comments.creator: benlu456@hotmail.com

bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.creator: bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.raw_text:
Hmm.  OK, I can reproduce this on Linux.

That said, the text inputs next to the button are totally different widths on Mac and Linux, because they're sized with size="16" and are using completely different fonts as far as I can tell.  I wouldn't be surprised if the font-family being used here is not available on Linux (or possibly not available on both) so we fall back to different things.

Are those text inputs on Linux in your case using the same fonts in Firefox and Chrome/Opera?  If so, which one is sizing them to be about 16 chars wide when measured like so: 01234567890123456 (using those exact characters)?
comments.text:
Hmm.  OK, I can reproduce this on Linux.

That said, the text inputs next to the button are totally different widths on Mac and Linux, because they're sized with size="16" and are using completely different fonts as far as I can tell.  I wouldn't be surprised if the font-family being used here is not available on Linux (or possibly not available on both) so we fall back to different things.

Are those text inputs on Linux in your case using the same fonts in Firefox and Chrome/Opera?  If so, which one is sizing them to be about 16 chars wide when measured like so: 01234567890123456 (using those exact characters)?

Yes, Opera uses different fonts indeed, I can see it on my blog
http://blog.nownews.com/djlu/
About Chromium I don't know, maybe it's a good direction.
